captions.text:
When you turn a car’s steering wheel, the
car follows a path along the same curve regardless

whether you go forwards or backwards. So it
seems like it should be just as easy to steer

going backwards as going forwards. But clearly,
it's not.

Suprisingly, the difficulty of driving backwards
has almost nothing to do with the direction

you’re facing and everything to do with
the fact that you steer using the front wheels.

When driving forwards, a car goes in the direction
the front wheels are pointed. And when driving

backwards, the car goes where the back wheels
are pointed. Simple! But the difference is

that going forwards, the direction of travel
is determined by the same wheels you steer

with, so you just point them where you want
to go, and that’s where you go, the back

wheels follow automatically. In physics, we
call this a “stable” system, like dangling

a pencil from your fingers – move your hand
around and the pencil follows, no thought
required.

However, when driving backwards, the direction
of travel is determined by the back wheels

but you steer with the front wheels. So rather
than just pointing the front wheels where

you want to go, you have to point them in
the direction that will get the BACK wheels

to point in the direction you want to go – it’s
an additional level of separation before the

car does what you want. And in fact, if you
don’t make any corrections, then over time

the back wheels point farther and farther
away from the direction you want to go: instead

of following the front wheels, they want to
run away!

This is an unstable system, like trying to
balance a pencil on your fingertip. It’s

incredibly finicky and requires a ton of coordinated
hand-eye feedback to maintain. That’s why

you constantly have to readjust your steering
when driving backwards – mathematically,
your car is like an upside-down pencil!

Of course, there are some successful rear-steering
wheeled vehicles – forklifts, for example,

drive only slowly and choose rear-steering
for greater control of their forks.

But let’s go in the other direction and
add a TRAILER to your car – steering backwards

has gained ANOTHER level of difficulty: you
use your front wheels to get the back wheels

to point in the direction needed to get the
TRAILER to point in the direction you want

to go. Not complicated enough? It becomes
worse the more trailers you add – each one

adds another level of separation between the
direction of your steering and the actual

direction of travel. Which is why it’s nearly
impossible to push on one end of a chain or

a rope and have the other end go where you
want it to, and why you will never, ever balance

a flexible rope or chain upright on your finger.
Makes backwards driving seem downright easy!

title: Why is it Harder to Drive Backwards?

comments.author: Chris Baker

comments.text:
The video is COMPLETELY WRONG until it gets to the part about trailers - 
then it's right. At low speed, if you're traveling forward, if you want to 
go to the place that's on the right, you turn the steering wheel to the 
right. If you're traveling backward, Looking In The Mirror, if you want to 
go to the place that's on the right, you turn the wheel to the right. 
Exactly the same! When you understand that, and practice it, it's no big 
deal. In both cases, you're turning the steering wheel toward the side of 
the car that you want the car to go to. Instability is not an issue. (At 
low speed. At higher speed, you get "oversteer", just like pushing a 
shopping cart backwards, but that's a separate issue.)Suppose you're not 
looking in a mirror, but turning your head around. But then you're confused 
by your head and your body having different opinions of where "right" is. 
So turn your whole body around, sit on the dashboard facing backward. (Have 
a good friend work the pedals.) It's exactly the same as if you were 
driving forward (except for the "oversteer" business if you're not going 
slow).
On the other hand, if you're trying to back up a trailer, it helps if your 
wheelbase is short, and the trailer's is long. Semi-drivers do that all the 
time. But if the trailer's wheelbase is short, it's very challenging, as it 
was when I was driving a tractor on a farm.﻿

comments.author: Jesusisyhwh

comments.text:
Hi, as an ex-driving instructor and scientist I need to explain that it is 
in fact not hard to steer backwards. I have given demonstrations of driving 
down country roads at 80 km/h in reverse. The instability you talk about is 
because of the "tow in" set on the front wheels. That is the left wheel is 
set to turn slightly to the right and the right wheel slightly to the left. 
The result of this is the car has a tendency to naturally steer straight if 
you let go of the steering wheel. However "tow in" going forward is "tow 
out" going backwards. So a car configured to be stable going forwards is 
hence configured to be unstable going the other way. Any car could be 
configured by a mechanic to be stable going backwards and not stable 
driving forwards.﻿

comments.author: Toyman Blood

comments.text:
Note: This also effects bikes, and planes, although planes slightly 
differently. A plane with canards at the front doesn't need to wait to be 
rotated, and the force from pulling the canards in a direction is exactly 
how you'd expect, in that direction.

On the other hand, a conventional aircraft, with elevators in the back, 
will sink somewhat from using them until the wings turn up sufficiently to 
generate more lift. In other words, the elevators compete with the wings, 
instead of adding to them.

On the other hand, canards (and bike and car front wheels) at a high angle 
of attack will normally stall before the wing (or the back tire). In a 
neutrally stable vehicle without a lot of angular inertia relative to the 
rotational drag, this is probably beneficial, but in other vehicles, it 
will limit angle of attack.﻿

comments.author: Michelle Nieroda

comments.text:
There is an adjustment on your vehicle's wheels called caster. Which is 
why your wheels automatically want to go strait when you drive forward. 
Just like the wheels on a shopping cart, except on a vehicle the wheels 
can't turn all the way around. So, due to this caster adjustment, when 
driving in reverse your vehicle will naturally want to go anywhere but 
strait. Forklifts have little to no caster adjustment on their turning 
wheels allowing for easier forward and backward driving.
I've only driven a forklift twice, but it was pretty much exactly the same 
as driving a car backwards while parking: the steering is harder in the 
sense that it is not stable (like balancing a pencil on your finger) but it 
allows you greater control over where the forklift goes when you are trying 
to make precise maneuvers. In both cases, it would suck to have to drive 
that way at normal road speeds, but it is a great way of making maneuvers 
in tight spaces.
